title: BIDS conversion example with toy data
text: create simple toy dataset participant information behavioral data. Note variables deliberately called like called according BIDS conventions. dataset contains three participants response times accuracy. participant completed one session reaction time task.
code: # Toy dataset example_data <- data.frame(   ParticipantID = c(1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3),   Gender=c("M", "F", "O", "M", "F", "O"),   Age=c(21, 32, 27, 21, 32, 27),   Session = c(1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 2),   ResponseTime = c(350, 400, 375, 415, 372, 401),   Accuracy = c(1, 0, 1, 1, 1, 1) )  # View the data print(example_data) #>   ParticipantID Gender Age Session ResponseTime Accuracy #> 1             1      M  21       1          350        1 #> 2             2      F  32       1          400        0 #> 3             3      O  27       1          375        1 #> 4             1      M  21       2          415        1 #> 5             2      F  32       2          372        1 #> 6             3      O  27       2          401        1

title: BIDS conversion example with toy data
text: creating BIDS dataset, ’s important ensure input data complies naming conventions (snake_case) contains necessary columns like participant IDs sessions. checking implemented check_input_data() function renames variables labels snake_case reports . Note creates new data set. Please check resulting set ensure everything correct. apply function toy data created last step. input data valid, can proceed next steps.
code: # Run validation example_data_checked <- check_input_data(data = example_data,                   participant_col = "ParticipantID",                   session_col = "Session",                   gender_col = "Gender") #>  #> Step 1: checking variable labels #> checking variable Gender #> renamed variable label: M -> m #> renamed variable label: F -> f #> renamed variable label: O -> o #>  #> Step 2: checking participant and session identifiers #> renamed variable: ParticipantID -> participant_id #> renamed ids to sub-001, sub-002, sub-003 ... #> renamed variable: Session -> session #> renamed sessions to ses-01, ses-02 ... #> renamed variable: Gender -> gender #>  #> Step 3: checking if all variable names are snake_case #> renamed variable: Age -> age #> renamed variable: ResponseTime -> response_time #> renamed variable: Accuracy -> accuracy #>  #> Step 4: checking correct coding of gender variable  print(example_data_checked) #>   participant_id gender age session response_time accuracy #> 1        sub-001      m  21  ses-01           350        1 #> 2        sub-002      f  32  ses-01           400        0 #> 3        sub-003      o  27  ses-01           375        1 #> 4        sub-001      m  21  ses-02           415        1 #> 5        sub-002      f  32  ses-02           372        1 #> 6        sub-003      o  27  ses-02           401        1

title: BIDS conversion example with toy data
text: Now, use write_bids function generate BIDS-compliant directory files. function performs following actions: Creates output directory (doesn’t already exist). Writes participants.tsv file includes participant IDs session numbers. Writes task-specific .tsv file behavioral data (response times, accuracy, etc.). find directory now containing desired files.
code: # Output directory (temporary for this example) output_dir <- "example_bids"  # Task name for BIDS task_name <- "reaction"  # Create the BIDS dataset write_bids(data = example_data_checked, output_dir = output_dir, task_name = task_name, participant_info_cols = c("age", "gender"), file_suffix = "beh") #> Participants data saved: example_bids/participants.tsv #> Task data saved: example_bids/sub-001/ses-01/sub-001_task-reaction_beh.tsv #> Task data saved: example_bids/sub-001/ses-02/sub-001_task-reaction_beh.tsv #> Task data saved: example_bids/sub-002/ses-01/sub-002_task-reaction_beh.tsv #> Task data saved: example_bids/sub-002/ses-02/sub-002_task-reaction_beh.tsv #> Task data saved: example_bids/sub-003/ses-01/sub-003_task-reaction_beh.tsv #> Task data saved: example_bids/sub-003/ses-02/sub-003_task-reaction_beh.tsv

what: Step 4: Define and Write JSON Metadata
title: BIDS conversion example with toy data
text: Next, define metadata task, describe behavioral variables recorded experiment (task data contained tsv files). metadata nested list element describes specific column dataset. nested lists descrbibe keys belonging variable. JSON file included BIDS structure can now easily written wirth function write_metadata(). JSON file added directory.
code: # Metadata for the example above with nested lists for each variable meta_data <- list(   participant_id = list(     Description = "Unique participant identifier in the format sub-XXX.",     Levels = list(       "sub-001" = "Participant 1",       "sub-002" = "Participant 2",       "sub-003" = "Participant 3"     )   ),   gender = list(     Description = "Self-reported gender of the participant.",     Levels = list(       "m" = "Male",       "f" = "Female",       "o" = "Other"     )   ),   age = list(     Description = "Age of the participant in years.",     Units = "years"   ),   session = list(     Description = "Session identifier.",     Levels = list(       "ses-01" = "First session",       "ses-02" = "Second session"     )   ),   response_time = list(     Description = "Response time of the participant in the task.",     Units = "milliseconds"   ),   accuracy = list(     Description = "Task accuracy (1 = correct, 0 = incorrect).",     Levels = list(       "0" = "Incorrect response",       "1" = "Correct response"     )   ) )  # View the metadata print(meta_data) #> $participant_id #> $participant_id$Description #> [1] "Unique participant identifier in the format sub-XXX." #>  #> $participant_id$Levels #> $participant_id$Levels$`sub-001` #> [1] "Participant 1" #>  #> $participant_id$Levels$`sub-002` #> [1] "Participant 2" #>  #> $participant_id$Levels$`sub-003` #> [1] "Participant 3" #>  #>  #>  #> $gender #> $gender$Description #> [1] "Self-reported gender of the participant." #>  #> $gender$Levels #> $gender$Levels$m #> [1] "Male" #>  #> $gender$Levels$f #> [1] "Female" #>  #> $gender$Levels$o #> [1] "Other" #>  #>  #>  #> $age #> $age$Description #> [1] "Age of the participant in years." #>  #> $age$Units #> [1] "years" #>  #>  #> $session #> $session$Description #> [1] "Session identifier." #>  #> $session$Levels #> $session$Levels$`ses-01` #> [1] "First session" #>  #> $session$Levels$`ses-02` #> [1] "Second session" #>  #>  #>  #> $response_time #> $response_time$Description #> [1] "Response time of the participant in the task." #>  #> $response_time$Units #> [1] "milliseconds" #>  #>  #> $accuracy #> $accuracy$Description #> [1] "Task accuracy (1 = correct, 0 = incorrect)." #>  #> $accuracy$Levels #> $accuracy$Levels$`0` #> [1] "Incorrect response" #>  #> $accuracy$Levels$`1` #> [1] "Correct response" write_metadata(output_dir = output_dir, task_name = task_name, meta_data = meta_data) #> Metadata JSON saved: example_bids/task-reaction_beh.json

what: Step 5: Read and Inspect the Generated Files
title: BIDS conversion example with toy data
text: files created, can laod function read_bids(). output list participant data task data. can see identical data generated Step 1.
code: data_loaded <- read_bids(bids_dir = "example_bids", task_name = task_name, file_suffix = "beh") #> Participants data loaded from: example_bids/participants.tsv #> Task data loaded from all task files. data_loaded$participants #>   participant_id age gender #> 1        sub-001  21      m #> 2        sub-002  32      f #> 3        sub-003  27      o data_loaded$task_data #>   participant_id session response_time accuracy #> 1        sub-001  ses-01           350        1 #> 2        sub-001  ses-02           415        1 #> 3        sub-002  ses-01           400        0 #> 4        sub-002  ses-02           372        1 #> 5        sub-003  ses-01           375        1 #> 6        sub-003  ses-02           401        1

title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: simple scenario, consider two stimuli (“taps”) presented skin two positions separated time. “simple” Bayesian Observer Model makes predictions spatiotemporal characteristics stimuli, spatial precisino touch sense, prior movement speed influence perceived positions stimuli. model, assume spatial precision touched positions idetical, hence called equal variance case. used terminology formulae based article Goldreich & Tong, 2013, PLOS ONE.

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: basic assumptions Bayesian Observer Model : stimuli (skin) never perceived perfect precision, skin’s spatial resolution imperfect therefore stimulus sensed certain (random) measurement error successive stimuli caused object moving along skin objects move realistic speed. , words, unlikely objects move fast stimuli therefore move far distance short time second assumption referred low-speed (: low-velocity) prior.

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances > Background information
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: hypotheses can derived described model : stimuli presented far apart fast perceptually attracted towards , .e. perceptual length contraction faster stimulation, stronger length contraction spatial distance stimuli, stronger length contraction higher precision, weaker length contraction stronger low-speed prior, stronger length contraction

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: model includes following parameters: \(x_{1m}\) \(x_{2m}\) “measured” “sensed” positions, .e. estimate given sensors corresponding stimulus positions \(x_1\) \(x_2\) inferred hypothetical stimulus positions \(t\) time (seconds) passing taps \(\sigma_s\) spatial standard deviation, uncertainty, referring sensed positions (\(x_{1m}\) \(x_{2m}\)). Higher values indicate lower precision. \(\sigma_v\) degree “low-speed” prior. Lower values indicate slower expected speed, , “stronger” prior. word units: Although units time space arbitrary long consistent, consistent use units literature. Usually, spatial units \(x_{1m}\), \(x_{2m}\), \(x_1\), \(x_1\), \(\sigma_s\) expressed cm units. time, \(t\) expressed seconds. low-speed prior \(\sigma_v\) expressed space per time units using cm seconds cm/s. \(\sigma_s\) sometimes conceptually referred average localization error, e.g. reference paper Weinstein (1968) 1 cm. Strictly speaking, however, refers standard deviation, variable error, spatial localization.

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: appendix article, formula prior distribution given Formula A08 : \[p(x_1,x_2|t) \propto p(x_2|x_1,t) = \frac {1} {\sqrt{2\pi}\sigma_vt} exp(-\frac {(x_2-x_1)^2}{2(\sigma_v t)^2})\]

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: formula likelihood distribution given Formula A10 : \[p(x_{1m},x_{2m}|x_1, x_2, t) = p(x_2|x_1,t) = p(x_{1m}|x_1)*p(x_{2m}|x_2)\] two conditional probabilities defined A11 : \[p(x_{1m}|x_1) = \frac {1} {\sqrt{2\pi}\sigma_s} exp \left(-\frac {(x_{1m}-x_1)^2}{2\sigma_s^2} \right)\] \[p(x_{2m}|x_2) = \frac {1} {\sqrt{2\pi}\sigma_s} exp \left(-\frac {(x_{2m}-x_2)^2}{2\sigma_s^2}\right)\] Following logically , likelihood computes : \[p(x_{1m},x_{2m}|x_1, x_2, t) = \frac {1} {\sqrt{2\pi}\sigma_s} exp \left(-\frac {(x_{2m}-x_2)^2}{2\sigma_s^2}\right) * \frac {1} {\sqrt{2\pi}\sigma_s} exp \left(-\frac {(x_{2m}-x_2)^2}{2\sigma_s^2} \right)\]

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: formula posterior distribution given A13 : \[p(x_1, x_2|x_{1m},x_{2m}, t) \propto exp \left( - \left( \frac {(x_{1m} - x_1)^2 + (x_{2m} - x_2)^2} {2\sigma_s ^2} + \frac {(x_2-x_1)^2}{(2\sigma_v t)^2} \right) \right)\] formula posterior distribution also formulated A14 : \[p(x_1, x_2|x_{1m},x_{2m}, t) \propto exp \left( -\frac {1} {2(1-\rho ^2)} \left( \frac {(x_1 - x_{1*})^2 + (x_2 - x_{2*})^2 - 2 \rho (x_1 - x_{1*}) (x_2 - x_{2*})} {\sigma ^2} \right) \right)\] However, unknowns appear equation defined A14. posterior modes, denoted \(x_{1*}\) \(x_{2*}\) defined : \[x_{1*}=x_{1m} \left( \frac {(\sigma_v t)^2 + \sigma_s ^2} {(\sigma_v t)^2 + 2\sigma_s ^2} \right) + x_{2m} \left( \frac {\sigma_s^2} {(\sigma_v t)^2 + 2\sigma_s ^2} \right)\] : \[x_{2*}=x_{2m} \left( \frac {(\sigma_v t)^2 + \sigma_s ^2} {(\sigma_v t)^2 + 2\sigma_s ^2} \right) + x_{1m} \left( \frac {\sigma_s^2} {(\sigma_v t)^2 + 2\sigma_s ^2} \right)\] correlation Gaussian distributions \(\rho\) given : \[\rho = \frac {\sigma_s^2} {\sigma_s^2 + (\sigma_v t)^2} \] Finally, combined variance \(\sigma^2\) given : \[\sigma^2 =  \sigma_s^2 \frac {\sigma_s^2 + (\sigma_v t)^2} {2\sigma_s^2 + (\sigma_v t)^2}\]

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: formulae presented , implemented rabBITS: Formula A08 implemented prior_2Tap() Formula A11 implemented likelihood_2Tap_EqVar() Formula A13 implemented posterior_2Tap_EqVar() (Parts ) Formula A14 implemented posterior_params_2Tap_EqVar() Note: R functions presented can also compute several values time, parameters passed vectors. see applications examples .

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: following, reproduce Figure 2 Goldreich & Tong, 2013.

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances > Reproduce Figure 2
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: following parameters used article used plotting.
code: ### Paramters of the stimuli and observer x1m=3 #measured positin of tap 1 (in cm) x2m=7 #measured positino of tap 2 (in cm) time_t = 0.15 #time between stimuli, i.e. interstimulus time (in seconds) sigma_s = 1 #spatial (im)precision (in cm as a sd) sigma_v = 10 #low speed prior   (in cm/s as an sd)

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances > Reproduce Figure 2
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: Compute values whole matrix
code: #params for plots x1_range <- c(0, 10) x2_range <- c(0, 10)  #resolution for graphs x1_res <- 100  x2_res <- 100  #matrix for the x1-x2 combinations x1x2Mat <- expand.grid(x1=seq(x1_range[1], x1_range[2], length.out = x1_res), x2=seq(x2_range[1], x2_range[2], length.out = x2_res)) ### XXX Compute prior density x1x2Mat$prior <- prior_2Tap(x1 = x1x2Mat$x1, x2 = x1x2Mat$x2, time_t = time_t, sigma_v = sigma_v)  ### XXX Compute likelihood x1x2Mat$likelihood <- likelihood_2Tap_EqVar(x1m=x1m, x2m=x2m, x1=x1x2Mat$x1, x2=x1x2Mat$x2, sigma_s = sigma_s)  ### XXX Compute posterior density x1x2Mat$posterior <- posterior_2Tap_EqVar(x1m=x1m, x2m=x2m, x1 = x1x2Mat$x1, x2 = x1x2Mat$x2, time_t = time_t, sigma_s = sigma_s, sigma_v = sigma_v)

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances > Reproduce Figure 2
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: Now create plot three distributions (like Figure 2).
code: #prior prior.plot <- ggplot(x1x2Mat, aes(x=x1, y=x2, fill=prior)) +   geom_raster() +   coord_fixed() +   ggtitle("prior") +   theme(legend.position = "none")  #likelihood likelihood.plot <- ggplot(x1x2Mat, aes(x=x1, y=x2, fill=likelihood)) +   geom_raster() +   coord_fixed() +   ggtitle("likelihood") +   theme(legend.position = "none")  #posterior posterior.plot <- ggplot(x1x2Mat, aes(x=x1, y=x2, fill=posterior)) +   geom_raster() +   coord_fixed() +   ggtitle("posterior") +   theme(legend.position = "none")  #join plots prior.plot + likelihood.plot + posterior.plot

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances > Reproduce Figure 2
what: Compute posterior modes and add to the plots
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: can also add real positions plots compute posterior means add well becomes better visible posterior dragged towards prior. posterior modes computed function posterior_params_2Tap_EqVar(). prior, likelihood, posterior distributions figure looks just like article.
code: #likelihood likelihood.plot <- likelihood.plot +   geom_point(x=x1m, y=x2m, size=2, color="white", shape=21, fill=NA) #measured position  #posterior modes Posterior_params <- posterior_params_2Tap_EqVar(x1m = x1m, x2m = x2m, time_t = time_t,                                      sigma_s = sigma_s, sigma_v = sigma_v)  Posterior_mode_x1 <- Posterior_params$x1_star Posterior_mode_x2 <- Posterior_params$x2_star  #version based on A13 posterior.plot <- posterior.plot +   geom_point(x=x1m, y=x2m, size=2, color="white", shape=21, fill=NA) + #measured position   geom_point(x=Posterior_mode_x1 , y=Posterior_mode_x2, size=2, color="red", shape=21, fill=NA) #posterior mode   #join plots p.joined <- prior.plot + likelihood.plot + posterior.plot p.joined

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances > Reproduce Figure 2
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: quick sanity check: compare analytically determined posterior modes ones can seen figure. can simply done finding value highest posterior probability numerically checking . can see values match quite well.
code:
#Posterior modes determined analytically print(paste("analytical values for x1:",              round(Posterior_mode_x1, 3),             "
 and for x2:",              round(Posterior_mode_x2, 3))) #> [1] "analytical values for x1: 3.941 
 and for x2: 6.059"  #Posterior mode determined numerically posteriorMax <- max(x1x2Mat$posterior) posteriorMax.index <- which(x1x2Mat$posterior==posteriorMax)  print(paste("numerical values for x1:",              round(x1x2Mat$x1[posteriorMax.index], 3),             "
 and for x2:",              round(x1x2Mat$x2[posteriorMax.index], 3))) #> [1] "numerical values for x1: 3.939 
 and for x2: 6.061"

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: section evaluate hypotheses mentioned varying model parameters.

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances > Addressing the hypotheses
what: Stimuli that are presented far apart and fast will be perceptually attracted towards each other
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: hypothesis inherently confirmed computations : note veridical stimuli presented positions 3 7 cm, respectively. distance 4 cm. posterior modes 3.9 6.1 cm. distance 2.2 cm. model accordingly predicts length contraction 4 - 2.2 = 1.8 cm set parameters.

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances > Addressing the hypotheses
what: The faster the stimulation, the stronger is the length contraction
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: address point, repeat model estimations different values \(t\), time passing two taps. stronger contraction shorter time t can seen figure, attraction stimuli towards according length contraction strong short time intervals stimuli disappears delays one second .
code: modelData <- data.frame(x1m=3, x2m=7, time_t=seq(0, 2, length.out=21), sigma_s=1, sigma_v=10)  #compute posterior modes modelData$pm_x1 <- with(modelData, posterior_params_2Tap_EqVar(x1m, x2m, time_t, sigma_s, sigma_v))$x1_star modelData$pm_x2 <- with(modelData, posterior_params_2Tap_EqVar(x1m, x2m, time_t, sigma_s, sigma_v))$x2_star  #create a plot modelData %>%    pivot_longer(cols = c(pm_x1, pm_x2), names_to = "posterior", values_to = "position") %>%    ggplot(aes(x=time_t, y=position, color=posterior)) +      geom_hline(yintercept = 7, linetype=2, color="grey") +      geom_hline(yintercept = 3, linetype=2, color="grey") +     geom_point() +      geom_path()

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances > Addressing the hypotheses
what: The further the travelled distance, the stronger the length contraction
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: show predictions scenario, keep t sigma_s constant vary positions taps. Note due small scale, decreased sigma_s parameter 0.1 emphasize effect. stronger (relative) contraction larger distances
code: modelData <- data.frame(x1m=0, x2m=seq(0.1, 1, length.out=10), time_t=0.015, sigma_s=0.1, sigma_v=10)  #compute posterior modes modelData$pm_x1 <- with(modelData, posterior_params_2Tap_EqVar(x1m, x2m, time_t, sigma_s, sigma_v))$x1_star modelData$pm_x2 <- with(modelData, posterior_params_2Tap_EqVar(x1m, x2m, time_t, sigma_s, sigma_v))$x2_star  #create a plot p1 <- modelData %>%    pivot_longer(cols = c(pm_x1, pm_x2), names_to = "posterior", values_to = "position") %>%    ggplot(aes(x=x2m, y=position, color=posterior)) +      geom_abline(intercept = 0, slope = 1, linetype=2, color="grey") +     xlim(0, 1) + ylim(0, 1) +     geom_point() +      geom_path() +     coord_fixed() +     ggtitle("posterior modes for \nvarying veridical distances")     #and another plot of the real distance vs. perceived distance   modelData <- modelData %>%    mutate(veridical=x2m-x1m, perceived=pm_x2-pm_x1) #compute real and perceived distances  p2 <- modelData %>%    ggplot(aes(x=veridical, y=perceived)) +    geom_abline(intercept = 0, slope = 1, linetype=2, color="grey") +   xlim(0, 1) + ylim(0, 1) +   geom_point() +    geom_path() +   coord_fixed() +   ggtitle("veridical vs. perceived \ndistances")  #merge plots p1 + p2

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances > Addressing the hypotheses
what: The higher the precision, the weaker the length contraction
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: time keep parameters parameters constant except sigma_s. stronger contraction lower precision
code: modelData <- data.frame(x1m=3, x2m=7, time_t=0.15, sigma_s=seq(0, 2, length.out=21), sigma_v=10)  #compute posterior modes modelData$pm_x1 <- with(modelData, posterior_params_2Tap_EqVar(x1m, x2m, time_t, sigma_s, sigma_v))$x1_star modelData$pm_x2 <- with(modelData, posterior_params_2Tap_EqVar(x1m, x2m, time_t, sigma_s, sigma_v))$x2_star  #create a plot modelData %>%    pivot_longer(cols = c(pm_x1, pm_x2), names_to = "posterior", values_to = "position") %>%      ggplot(aes(x=sigma_s, y=position, color=posterior)) +      geom_hline(yintercept = 7, linetype=2, color="grey") +      geom_hline(yintercept = 3, linetype=2, color="grey") +     geom_point() +      geom_path() +     ggtitle("posterior modes for \nvarying spatial precisions")

previous_headings: Two-tap case with equal variances > Addressing the hypotheses
what: The stronger the low-speed prior, the stronger the length contraction
title: The two-tap scenario with equal variances
text: Finally, low-speed prior varied parameter. stronger contraction lower expected speed
code: modelData <- data.frame(x1m=3, x2m=7, time_t=0.15, sigma_s=1, sigma_v=seq(0, 10, length.out=21))  #compute posterior modes modelData$pm_x1 <- with(modelData, posterior_params_2Tap_EqVar(x1m, x2m, time_t, sigma_s, sigma_v))$x1_star modelData$pm_x2 <- with(modelData, posterior_params_2Tap_EqVar(x1m, x2m, time_t, sigma_s, sigma_v))$x2_star  #create a plot modelData %>%    pivot_longer(cols = c(pm_x1, pm_x2), names_to = "posterior", values_to = "position") %>%      ggplot(aes(x=sigma_v, y=position, color=posterior)) +      geom_hline(yintercept = 7, linetype=2, color="grey") +      geom_hline(yintercept = 3, linetype=2, color="grey") +     geom_point() +      geom_path() +     ggtitle("posterior modes for \nvarying speed priors")

title: The two-tap scenario with unequal variances
text: previous article [REF], covered special case (inverse) spatial precision,sigma_s spatial positions. often realistic, spatial resolution skin varies sections skin, even along one limb. can addressed generalized form model, takes single precision parameters tap 1 2.

previous_headings: Two-tap case with unequal variances
what: Prior-Likelihood-Posterior figure with unewual spatial variance
title: The two-tap scenario with unequal variances
text: create different version figure, sigma_s1, inverse precision tap 1, 1 sigma_s2, inverse precisino tap 2, takes value 2.

previous_headings: Two-tap case with unequal variances > Prior-Likelihood-Posterior figure with unewual spatial variance
title: The two-tap scenario with unequal variances
text: following parameters used article used plotting.
code: ### Paramters of the stimuli and observer x1m=3 #measured positin of tap 1 (in cm) x2m=7 #measured positino of tap 2 (in cm) time_t = 0.15 #time between stimuli, i.e. interstimulus time (in seconds) sigma_s1 = 1 #spatial (im)precision (in cm as a sd) sigma_s2 = 3 #spatial (im)precision (in cm as a sd) sigma_v = 10 #low speed prior   (in cm/s as an sd)

previous_headings: Two-tap case with unequal variances > Prior-Likelihood-Posterior figure with unewual spatial variance
title: The two-tap scenario with unequal variances
text: Compute values whole matrix
code: #params for plots x1_range <- c(0, 10) x2_range <- c(0, 10)  #resolution for graphs x1_res <- 100  x2_res <- 100  #matrix for the x1-x2 combinations x1x2Mat <- expand.grid(x1=seq(x1_range[1], x1_range[2], length.out = x1_res), x2=seq(x2_range[1], x2_range[2], length.out = x2_res)) ### XXX Compute prior density x1x2Mat$prior <- prior_2Tap(x1 = x1x2Mat$x1, x2 = x1x2Mat$x2, time_t = time_t, sigma_v = sigma_v)  ### XXX Compute likelihood x1x2Mat$likelihood <- likelihood_2Tap_UneqVar(x1m=x1m, x2m=x2m, x1=x1x2Mat$x1, x2=x1x2Mat$x2, sigma_s1 = sigma_s1, sigma_s2 = sigma_s2)  ### XXX Compute posterior density x1x2Mat$posterior <- posterior_2Tap_UneqVar(x1m=x1m, x2m=x2m, x1 = x1x2Mat$x1, x2 = x1x2Mat$x2, time_t = time_t, sigma_s1 = sigma_s1, sigma_s2 = sigma_s2, sigma_v = sigma_v)

previous_headings: Two-tap case with unequal variances > Prior-Likelihood-Posterior figure with unewual spatial variance
title: The two-tap scenario with unequal variances
text: Now create plot three distributions (like Figure 2).
code: #prior prior.plot <- ggplot(x1x2Mat, aes(x=x1, y=x2, fill=prior)) +   geom_raster() +   coord_fixed() +   ggtitle("prior") +   theme(legend.position = "none")  #likelihood likelihood.plot <- ggplot(x1x2Mat, aes(x=x1, y=x2, fill=likelihood)) +   geom_raster() +   coord_fixed() +   ggtitle("likelihood") +   theme(legend.position = "none")  #posterior posterior.plot <- ggplot(x1x2Mat, aes(x=x1, y=x2, fill=posterior)) +   geom_raster() +   coord_fixed() +   ggtitle("posterior") +   theme(legend.position = "none")

previous_headings: Two-tap case with unequal variances > Prior-Likelihood-Posterior figure with unewual spatial variance
what: Compute posterior modes and add to the plots
title: The two-tap scenario with unequal variances
text: can also add real positions plots compute posterior means add well becomes better visible posterior dragged towards prior. posterior modes computed function {r posterior_params_2Tap_EqVar()} prior, likelihood, posterior distributions
code: #likelihood likelihood.plot <- likelihood.plot +   geom_point(x=x1m, y=x2m, size=2, color="white", shape=21, fill=NA) #measured position  #posterior modes Posterior_params <- posterior_params_2Tap_UneqVar(x1m = x1m, x2m = x2m, time_t = time_t,                                      sigma_s1 = sigma_s1, sigma_s2 = sigma_s2, sigma_v = sigma_v)  Posterior_mode_x1 <- Posterior_params$x1_star Posterior_mode_x2 <- Posterior_params$x2_star  #update posterior plot posterior.plot <- posterior.plot +   geom_point(x=x1m, y=x2m, size=2, color="white", shape=21, fill=NA) + #measured position   geom_point(x=Posterior_mode_x1 , y=Posterior_mode_x2, size=2, color="red", shape=21, fill=NA) #posterior mode   #join plots p.joined <- prior.plot + likelihood.plot + posterior.plot p.joined

previous_headings: Two-tap case with unequal variances > Prior-Likelihood-Posterior figure with unewual spatial variance
title: The two-tap scenario with unequal variances
text: quick sanity check: compare analytically determined posterior modes ones can seen figure. can simply done finding value highest posterior probability numerically checking .
code:
#Posterior modes determined analytically print(paste("analytical values for x1:",              round(Posterior_mode_x1, 3),             "
 and for x2:",              round(Posterior_mode_x2, 3))) #> [1] "analytical values for x1: 3.327 
 and for x2: 4.061"  #Posterior mode determined numerically posteriorMax <- max(x1x2Mat$posterior) posteriorMax.index <- which(x1x2Mat$posterior==posteriorMax)  print(paste("numerical values for x1:",              round(x1x2Mat$x1[posteriorMax.index], 3),             "
 and for x2:",              round(x1x2Mat$x2[posteriorMax.index], 3))) #> [1] "numerical values for x1: 3.333 
 and for x2: 4.04"

title: Authors and Citation
text: Xaver Fuchs. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Fuchs X (2024). r2bids: Convert R data frames behavioral data Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) format. R package version 0.0.1, https://xaverfuchs.github.io/r2bids/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {r2bids: Convert R data frames with behavioral data to the Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) format},   author = {Xaver Fuchs},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.0.1},   url = {https://xaverfuchs.github.io/r2bids/}, }

what: Convert R data frames with behavioral data to the Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) format
title: Convert R data frames with behavioral data to the Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) format
text: package provides functions converting storing data reprensented R data frames convenient BIDS format. BIDS format becoming increasingly popular neuroscience means storing data sets along structured descriptions samples, tasks, variables.

title: Convert R data frames with behavioral data to the Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) format
text: Read detailed documentation including examples … https://xaverfuchs.github.io/r2bids/

title: Convert R data frames with behavioral data to the Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) format
text: can install development version r2bids GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") # devtools::install_github("xaverfuchs/r2bids")

title: Convert R data frames with behavioral data to the Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) format
code: library(r2bids)

previous_headings: Example case
title: Convert R data frames with behavioral data to the Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) format
code: example_data <- data.frame(   ParticipantID = c(1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3),   Gender=c("M", "F", "O", "M", "F", "O"),   Age=c(21, 32, 27, 21, 32, 27),   Session = c(1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 2),   ResponseTime = c(350, 400, 375, 415, 372, 401),   Accuracy = c(1, 0, 1, 1, 1, 1) )

previous_headings: Example case
title: Convert R data frames with behavioral data to the Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) format
text: function renaming variables labels adhere BIDS conventions.
code: example_data_checked <- check_input_data(data = example_data,                   participant_col = "ParticipantID",                   session_col = "Session",                   gender_col = "Gender") #>  #> Step 1: checking variable labels #> checking variable Gender #> renamed variable label: M -> m #> renamed variable label: F -> f #> renamed variable label: O -> o #>  #> Step 2: checking participant and session identifiers #> renamed variable: ParticipantID -> participant_id #> renamed ids to sub-001, sub-002, sub-003 ... #> renamed variable: Session -> session #> renamed sessions to ses-01, ses-02 ... #> renamed variable: Gender -> gender #>  #> Step 3: checking if all variable names are snake_case #> renamed variable: Age -> age #> renamed variable: ResponseTime -> response_time #> renamed variable: Accuracy -> accuracy #>  #> Step 4: checking correct coding of gender variable

previous_headings: Example case
title: Convert R data frames with behavioral data to the Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) format
code: write_bids(data = example_data_checked, output_dir = "./readme_files/example_bids", task_name = "reaction", participant_info_cols = c("age", "gender"), file_suffix = "beh") #> Participants data saved: ./readme_files/example_bids/participants.tsv #> Task data saved: ./readme_files/example_bids/sub-001/ses-01/sub-001_task-reaction_beh.tsv #> Task data saved: ./readme_files/example_bids/sub-001/ses-02/sub-001_task-reaction_beh.tsv #> Task data saved: ./readme_files/example_bids/sub-002/ses-01/sub-002_task-reaction_beh.tsv #> Task data saved: ./readme_files/example_bids/sub-002/ses-02/sub-002_task-reaction_beh.tsv #> Task data saved: ./readme_files/example_bids/sub-003/ses-01/sub-003_task-reaction_beh.tsv #> Task data saved: ./readme_files/example_bids/sub-003/ses-02/sub-003_task-reaction_beh.tsv

previous_headings: Example case
what: Define Metadata and write JSON file
title: Convert R data frames with behavioral data to the Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) format
text: resulting output looks like : detailed example see vignettes package website!
code: # Metadata for the example above with nested lists for each variable meta_data <- list(   participant_id = list(     Description = "Unique participant identifier in the format sub-XXX.",     Levels = list(       "sub-001" = "Participant 1",       "sub-002" = "Participant 2",       "sub-003" = "Participant 3"     )   ),   gender = list(     Description = "Self-reported gender of the participant.",     Levels = list(       "m" = "Male",       "f" = "Female",       "o" = "Other"     )   ),   age = list(     Description = "Age of the participant in years.",     Units = "years"   ),   session = list(     Description = "Session identifier.",     Levels = list(       "ses-01" = "First session",       "ses-02" = "Second session"     )   ),   response_time = list(     Description = "Response time of the participant in the task.",     Units = "milliseconds"   ),   accuracy = list(     Description = "Task accuracy (1 = correct, 0 = incorrect).",     Levels = list(       "0" = "Incorrect response",       "1" = "Correct response"     )   ) ) write_metadata(output_dir = "./readme_files/example_bids", task_name = "reaction", meta_data = meta_data) #> Metadata JSON saved: ./readme_files/example_bids/task-reaction_beh.json

what: Validate and preprocess the input data for BIDS formatting — check_input_data
title: Validate and preprocess the input data for BIDS formatting — check_input_data
text: function checks certain requirements met dataset, including variable names snake_case, valid participant IDs, session description. function can optionally also check proper gender encoding ("m", "f", "o"). attempts convert invalid data outputs warnings errors issues arise.

title: Validate and preprocess the input data for BIDS formatting — check_input_data
code: check_input_data(   data,   participant_col = "participant_id",   session_col = "session",   gender_col = NULL )

title: Validate and preprocess the input data for BIDS formatting — check_input_data
text: data data frame contains dataset validated. participant_col Name column containing participant IDs (default "participant_id"). session_col Name column containing session IDs (default "session"). gender_col Name column containing gender information, (default NULL, assuming gender column).

title: Validate and preprocess the input data for BIDS formatting — check_input_data
text: validated possibly modified data frame appropriate formatting.

title: Validate and preprocess the input data for BIDS formatting — check_input_data
code: # Example dataset example_data <- data.frame(ParticipantID = c(1, 2), Session = c(1, 1), Gender = c("Male", "Female")) check_input_data(data = example_data, participant_col = "ParticipantID", session_col = "Session", gender_col = "Gender") #>  #> Step 1: checking variable labels #> checking variable Gender #> renamed variable label: Male -> male #> renamed variable label: Female -> female #>  #> Step 2: checking participant and session identifiers #> renamed variable: ParticipantID -> participant_id #> renamed ids to sub-001, sub-002 ... #> renamed variable: Session -> session #> renamed sessions to ses-01 ... #> renamed variable: Gender -> gender #>  #> Step 3: checking if all variable names are snake_case #> renamed variable: NA -> NA #> renamed variable:  ->  #>  #> Step 4: checking correct coding of gender variable #> Warning: Invalid values found in gender column. Please recode to 'm', 'f', or 'o'. #>   participant_id session gender #> 1        sub-001  ses-01   male #> 2        sub-002  ses-01 female

what: Compute likelihood for the two-tap scenario with equal spatial variance — likelihood_2Tap_EqVar
title: Compute likelihood for the two-tap scenario with equal spatial variance — likelihood_2Tap_EqVar
text: function computes likelihood values given trajectory. code refers two-tap model equal variance (spatial uncertainty) taps described Goldreich & Tong (2013), given Formula A11.

title: Compute likelihood for the two-tap scenario with equal spatial variance — likelihood_2Tap_EqVar
code: likelihood_2Tap_EqVar(x1m, x2m, x1, x2, sigma_s)

title: Compute likelihood for the two-tap scenario with equal spatial variance — likelihood_2Tap_EqVar
text: x1m measured/sensed hypothetical position tap 1 likelihood (p given parameters) computed x2m measured/sensed hypothetical position tap 2 x1 (real) position tap 1 x2 (real) position tap 1 sigma_s spatial uncertainty (given standard deviation) taps (sd assumed positions)

title: Compute likelihood for the two-tap scenario with equal spatial variance — likelihood_2Tap_EqVar
text: likelihood values (see article details vignette two-tap scenario). x1 x2 vectors, vector likelihood values returned.

title: Compute likelihood for the two-tap scenario with equal spatial variance — likelihood_2Tap_EqVar
text: Goldreich & Tong, 2013, Frontiers Psychology

title: Compute likelihood for the two-tap scenario with equal spatial variance — likelihood_2Tap_EqVar
code: require(rabBITS) #> Loading required package: rabBITS  #XXX Example 1: compute a single point estimate XXX likelihood_2Tap_EqVar(x1m=2, x2m=4, x1=1, x2=2, sigma_s=1) #> [1] 0.01306423  #XXX Example 2: plot a likelihood function for combinations of tap 1 and 2 XXX library(ggplot2) x1_range <- c(0, 10) #range for taps x2_range <- c(0, 10)  x1_res <- 100 #resolution for graphs x2_res <- 100  likelihoodMat <- expand.grid(x1=seq(x1_range[1], x1_range[2], length.out=x1_res), x2=seq(x2_range[1], x2_range[2], length.out=x2_res)) likelihoodMat$l <- likelihood_2Tap_EqVar(x1m=2, x2m=4, x1=likelihoodMat$x1, x2=likelihoodMat$x2, sigma_s=1) ggplot(likelihoodMat, aes(x=x1, y=x2, fill=l)) +   geom_raster() +   coord_fixed() +   ggtitle("likelihood")

code: require(rabBITS)  #XXX Example 1: compute a single point estimate XXX likelihood_2Tap_UneqVar(x1m=2, x2m=4, x1=1, x2=2, sigma_s1=1, sigma_s2=2) #> [1] 0.1170997  #XXX Example 2: plot likelihood function for combinations of tap 1 and 2 XXX library(ggplot2) x1_range <- c(0, 10) #range for taps x2_range <- c(0, 10)  x1_res <- 100 #resolution for graphs x2_res <- 100  likelihoodMat <- expand.grid(x1=seq(x1_range[1], x1_range[2], length.out=x1_res), x2=seq(x2_range[1], x2_range[2], length.out=x2_res)) likelihoodMat$l <- likelihood_2Tap_UneqVar(x1m=2, x2m=4, x1=likelihoodMat$x1, x2=likelihoodMat$x2, sigma_s1=1, sigma_s2=2) ggplot(likelihoodMat, aes(x=x1, y=x2, fill=l)) +   geom_raster() +   coord_fixed() +   ggtitle("likelihood")

what: Compute posterior probability density for the two-tap scenario with equal spatial variance — posterior_2Tap_EqVar
title: Compute posterior probability density for the two-tap scenario with equal spatial variance — posterior_2Tap_EqVar
text: function computes  values proportional posterior probability values given trajectory. code refers two-tap model equal variance (spatial uncertainty) taps described Goldreich & Tong (2013), given Formula A13.

title: Compute posterior probability density for the two-tap scenario with equal spatial variance — posterior_2Tap_EqVar
code: posterior_2Tap_EqVar(x1m, x2m, x1, x2, time_t, sigma_s, sigma_v)

title: Compute posterior probability density for the two-tap scenario with equal spatial variance — posterior_2Tap_EqVar
text: x1m measured/sensed hypothetical position tap 1 likelihood (p given parameters) computed x2m measured/sensed hypothetical position tap 2 x1 (real) position tap 1 x2 (real) position tap 1 time_t speed prior (units space per time; given standard deviation) sigma_s spatial uncertainty (given standard deviation) taps (sd assumed positions) sigma_v speed prior (units space per time; given standard deviation)

title: Compute posterior probability density for the two-tap scenario with equal spatial variance — posterior_2Tap_EqVar
text: values proportional posterior probability given trajectory. x1 x2 vectors, vector probabilities returned. Note returned values strictly speaking probabilities normalized (see article details vignette two-tap scenario).

title: Compute posterior probability density for the two-tap scenario with equal spatial variance — posterior_2Tap_EqVar
text: Goldreich & Tong, 2013, Frontiers Psychology

title: Compute posterior probability density for the two-tap scenario with equal spatial variance — posterior_2Tap_EqVar
code: #XXX Example 1: compute a single point estimate XXX posterior_2Tap_EqVar(x1m=2, x2m=4, x1=2, x2=4, sigma_s=1, sigma_v=10, time_t=0.1) #> [1] 0.1353353  #XXX Example 2: plot a posterior distribution for combinations of tap 1 and 2 XXX library(ggplot2) x1_range <- c(0, 10) #range for taps x2_range <- c(0, 10)  x1_res <- 100 #resolution for graphs x2_res <- 100  posteriorMat <- expand.grid(x1=seq(x1_range[1], x1_range[2], length.out=x1_res), x2=seq(x2_range[1], x2_range[2], length.out=x2_res))  posteriorMat$p <- posterior_2Tap_EqVar(x1m=2, x2m=4, x1=posteriorMat$x1, x2=posteriorMat$x2, sigma_s=1, sigma_v=10, time_t=0.1)  ggplot(posteriorMat, aes(x=x1, y=x2, fill=p)) +   geom_raster() +   coord_fixed() +   ggtitle("posterior")

text: Goldreich & Tong, 2013, Frontiers Psychology

title: Compute prior probability density for the two-tap scenario — prior_2Tap
code: require(rabBITS)  #XXX Example 1: compute a single point estimate XXX prior_2Tap(x1=2, x2=4, sigma_v=10, time_t=0.1) #> [1] 0.05399097  #XXX Example 2: compute a whole vector of combinations of tap 1 and 2 XXX prior_2Tap(x1=1, x2=c(1:10), sigma_v=10, time_t=0.1) #>  [1] 3.989423e-01 2.419707e-01 5.399097e-02 4.431848e-03 1.338302e-04 #>  [6] 1.486720e-06 6.075883e-09 9.134720e-12 5.052271e-15 1.027977e-18  #XXX Example 3: plot a prior distribution for combinations of tap 1 and 2 XXX library(ggplot2) x1_range <- c(0, 10) #range for taps x2_range <- c(0, 10)  x1_res <- 100 #resolution for graphs x2_res <- 100  priorMat <- expand.grid(x1=seq(x1_range[1], x1_range[2], length.out=x1_res), x2=seq(x2_range[1], x2_range[2], length.out=x2_res)) priorMat$p <- prior_2Tap(x1=priorMat$x1, x2=priorMat$x2, sigma_v=10, time_t=0.1) ggplot(priorMat, aes(x=x1, y=x2, fill=p)) +   geom_raster() +   coord_fixed() +   ggtitle("prior")

title: Read BIDS-formatted data — read_bids
text: function searches BIDS directory task-related .tsv files reads data R. handles cases session folders present well cases session folders.

title: Read BIDS-formatted data — read_bids
code: read_bids(bids_dir, task_name, file_suffix = "beh")

title: Read BIDS-formatted data — read_bids
text: bids_dir root directory BIDS dataset. task_name name task (e.g., "reaction"). file_suffix suffix task files (e.g., "beh", "events"). Default "beh".

title: Read BIDS-formatted data — read_bids
text: list containing participant data task data.

what: Convert a string to snake_case — to_snake_case
title: Convert a string to snake_case — to_snake_case
text: function converts given string snake_case replacing spaces special characters underscores converting letters lowercase.

title: Convert a string to snake_case — to_snake_case
code: to_snake_case(string)

title: Convert a string to snake_case — to_snake_case
text: string character string needs converted snake_case.

title: Convert a string to snake_case — to_snake_case
text: snake_case version input string.

title: Convert a string to snake_case — to_snake_case
code: to_snake_case("Hello World") #> [1] "hello_world" to_snake_case("ConvertThisString") #> [1] "convert_this_string"

what: Create BIDS-compliant behavioral data files — write_bids
title: Create BIDS-compliant behavioral data files — write_bids
text: function creates BIDS-compliant behavioral data files .tsv format. generates participants file (participants.tsv) individual task-based files participant session.

title: Create BIDS-compliant behavioral data files — write_bids
code: write_bids(   data,   output_dir,   task_name,   participant_info_cols,   file_suffix = "beh" )

title: Create BIDS-compliant behavioral data files — write_bids
text: data data frame containing participant information behavioral data. output_dir directory BIDS dataset saved. task_name Name task, used filename. participant_info_cols character vector column names include participants.tsv file. variables now included tsv files containing task data. file_suffix string defining suffix task files. BIDS usually "events" "beh" (default) "behavior"

title: Create BIDS-compliant behavioral data files — write_bids
text: function return anything writes files output directory.

title: Create BIDS-compliant behavioral data files — write_bids
code: data <- data.frame(participant_id = c(1, 1, 2, 2),                    session = c(1, 2, 1, 2),                    age = c(25, 25, 30, 30),                    gender = c('m', 'm', 'f', 'f'),                    response_time = c(100, 200, 150, 180)) write_bids(data, output_dir = "bids_dir", task_name = "RTTask", participant_info_cols = c("age", "gender")) #> Main BIDS directory successfully created: bids_dir #> Participants data saved: bids_dir/participants.tsv #> Folder successfully created: bids_dir/1/1 #> Task data saved: bids_dir/1/1/1_task-RTTask_beh.tsv #> Folder successfully created: bids_dir/1/2 #> Task data saved: bids_dir/1/2/1_task-RTTask_beh.tsv #> Folder successfully created: bids_dir/2/1 #> Task data saved: bids_dir/2/1/2_task-RTTask_beh.tsv #> Folder successfully created: bids_dir/2/2 #> Task data saved: bids_dir/2/2/2_task-RTTask_beh.tsv

title: Write BIDS JSON Metadata — write_metadata
text: function creates BIDS-compliant JSON metadata file task data.

title: Write BIDS JSON Metadata — write_metadata
code: write_metadata(output_dir, task_name, meta_data)

title: Write BIDS JSON Metadata — write_metadata
text: output_dir directory BIDS metadata file saved. task_name name task include JSON filename. meta_data named list containing metadata behavioral task.

title: Write BIDS JSON Metadata — write_metadata
text: function return anything writes JSON file output directory.

title: Write BIDS JSON Metadata — write_metadata
code: meta_data <- list(response_time = "Response time in milliseconds") write_metadata(output_dir = getwd(), task_name = "reaction_time", meta_data = meta_data) #> Metadata JSON saved: /Users/b1082752/Library/Mobile Documents/com~apple~CloudDocs/WORK TEMP/12_openscience/r2bids/docs/reference/task-reaction_time_beh.json
